channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #212 - Come For the Code, Stay For the Community
item.description: Yesterday was CPAN day: the 20th(!) anniversary of the day CPAN appeared online. A few articles of this week's edition celebrate the event, and promote the kind of interaction that keeps it alive. Which is wonderful, it really is. But for me the greatest articles of this week are the two that go beyond the code and talk about the community behind it. Not because our community is perfect, far from it, nor because it's without its problems, but because we do a few things right. Like hugs. We do hugs really well. And, frankly, if a community gets that right, it got the architectural thing all figured out; the rest is merely implemention details. Enjoy! ~ `/anick
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: Morgan Stanley Budapest Perl developer for cloud
item.description: Create internal cloud hosting solutions within Morgan Stanley. As a contributor on our budapest-based team, you will have responsibility to contribute not only to the code, but to the design and engineering of the full PaaS systems.

item.title: Front-end with AngularJS, Back-end with Perl Dancer and MongoDB
item.description: There are going to be 3 courses at YAPC::EU in Granada, Spain. At one of them you can learn how to use Angular JS together with Perl Dancer.

item.title: Swiss Perl Workshop - Register (and Get Prepared) for the Perl 6 Hackathon
item.description: The Swiss Perl Workshop, it's coooooming! Are you ready?

item.title: Seeking helpers for Net::DHCP
item.description: Dean has fired a distress flare. Will any ship nearby answer its call?

item.title: Booking.com Donate $60,000 to Perl 5
item.description: Booking.com donated $60K to The Perl Fundation toward the continued support of the Perl 5 Core. To which I can only say: "huzzah!"

item.title: MongoDB Perl driver v1.0.0 RC 2 available - please test!
item.description: If you are using MongoDB, this is likely a module lying deeply into your stack. And its next release is going to be a big, scary, bump-it-to-one-dot-oh release. Wisdom says you might just want to give its trial version a whirl before things get irrevocable.

item.title: SQLite -> Postgres = Much ranting
item.description: Changing database type in your app, it's as simple as changing 'dbi:SQLite:...' for 'dbi:Pg:...', right? Well, not quite. Jess shares how SQLite's idiosyncrazies were surprising and delighting. Well, surprising for sure; "delighting"?, not so sure.

item.title: What's your favourite CPAN module?
item.description: If you love a CPAN module, clap your hands! Or tell the author about it. Or provide a little "thank you" type of patch. Or blog about it.

item.title: How the Perl community embraces diversity
item.description: Sometimes, you hear that someone "is a little rough, but they have their heart at the right place". I often have that feel about the Perl community. We're dysfunctional, opiniated, volatile, of dubious manners at times but, deep down, the kids are all right.

item.title: Raise hell, or bugs, on CPAN Day!
item.description: Sure, CPAN day is over by now. But let's be honest, raising hell shouldn't be restricted to a single day in the year, now, should it?

item.title: The Perl Community
item.description: Any online community is pretty much a herd of cats. But it could be argued that the Perl community is even a disparater clowder than most. Preparing his panel for YAPC::EU, Andrew muses on what constitute the community, and how to extend it even further.

item.title: Swat and Mojolicious
item.description: Want to try a new way to test your Mojolicious applications? melezhik might have something for you.

item.title: Review a git branch in the terminal
item.description: When you'd prefer not to leave the command-line while comparing Git branches.

item.title: CPAN Patch Workflow II
item.description: Now that his patches has been accepted into Git-CPAN-Patch, fREW shows how 'git cpan send-email' can be used to send PRs via RT.

item.title: Converting glob patterns to regular expressions
item.description: If programming constructs were Pokemons, glob patterns would be the first form of regular expressions. mauke shows us here how to manualy make them evolve to their final form.

item.title: Port scanning with Perl, Part II
item.description: Perl is pretty good at that kind of stuff. And David is pretty good at explaining it.

item.title: The Onset Of Upheaval
item.description: This week, a brooding thundercloud called "Great List Refactor" -- what is hoped to be the last big storm before Christmas -- appears at the edge of the Perl6 skyscape.

item.title: Mystery Line in Proc Input in Perl 6
item.description: Sometimes, it's a feature. Sometimes, it's a bug. Sometimes, sometimes you just don't know.

item.title: CPAN great modules released last week
Reporting diskspace usage on a mail server (screencast)
Git branches considered harmful
item.description: Git branches: boon of parallel development or danger to us all? Pieter thinks it's the latter. I... am not sure I agree with his conclusions. Actually, I'm fairly sure I don't agree with his conclusions. But still, it's always a good thing to hear opinions coming from different angles on the topic.

item.title: Trust no one
item.description: In the software world, it's not because it's obvious that it should be taken for granted. Ricardo is using a cute app to control his mouse from wherever he is. Obviously, something manipulating such a crucial function would use an encrypted connection, right?

item.title: TODO in AngularJS
item.description: The rite of passage entering the land of AngularJS.
